div.head: Translation
div.p: Titus Pompeius Ligyrus, from Autricum, aged 40, cavalryman of the the cohort of Spaniards, having served 20 years, lies here; Clemens, for his patron.

div.head: Commentary
div.p: I assessed letterforms to be early, that of course is highly subjective, and it must be admitted that in Cyrenaica where most inscriptions are in Greek the number of dated Latin texts for comparison is small.

On this text see W. Wagner Die Dislocation das r√∂mischen Auxiliarformationen in den Provinzen Noricum, Pannonien, Moesiem und Dakie; The text was dated by Ghislanzoni in the second century C.E. But letter forms and formulae (eque ex cohorte, aera = stipendium, hic situs) suggest rather the first half of First century C.E. if that is correct we must reject the suggestion of Romanelli, Cirenaica 192f., followed by Applebaum, JJS II (1950)30, that the cohort (perhaps II Hispanorum Scutata Cyrenaica, see Romanelli, line c. and CIL XVI, 110 of 159 A.D). had been temporarily moved from its normal station on the Danube during the Jewish Revolt of 115 C.E. The inscription must belong to an earlier phase in the history of the cohort, before it went to the Danube region.

line 2 Since Ligyrus had belonged to a Spanish cohort, Wagner is probably right to refer his ethnic to the Autrigones or Autricones of Tarraconensis, rather than to Autricum as proposed by previous editors.
line 7 Also in C47900, lines4-5, q.v. for a discussion of its identity; see also P31600.
line 8. This form seems to have been particularly popular in Spain, see Ritterling, line c.
The absence of the dedication dis manibus, in any of its forms and the use of nominative case for the subject are again suggestive of the first century rather than a later date.

There are some indications to suggest that the men concerned were actually Spaniards, and if so, it is probable, although of course not certain that they were in service comparatively soon after the unit was recruited, or at least, after it left Spain. Thus Pompeius Ligyrus is perhaps better regarded as a man of Cantabrian tribe of Autricones (Autrigones) than as supposed at first a man from Autricum; both he and Sempronius Macer bear nomina which are relatively common in Spain as a result of the Gracchan and Pompeian connections with the peninsula (Aemilius is common enough there too, but not particularly characteristic); a possible explanation of the four letters in number two, line 4 is Tarr(aconensis). As against all this it must be said that it is unexpected to find three full Roman citizens serving as auxiliaries in the first century (four if the brother Aemilius Macer is assumed to be fellow soldier), two of them sons of Roman citizens. It is also rare for auxiliary men to mention ranks in the first century but not unknown. Neither can be regarded as absolute bars to a first century date. If a first century date were accepted it would be reasonable hypothesis, I think, that the unit was brought to Cyrenaica in the course of the Marmaric War of the Augustan period and remainded in garrison there for a time thereafter. An armed garrison at Cyrene itself and in Ptolemais is fully understandable in this context; detachments may well have been placedfor a time in all the cities of the province. subsequently units may have been sent away and those that remained seem to have been withdrawn to the limes forts.
